docs.lead_paragraph: High-speed police chases that cause death or injury do not violate the Constitution unless the police acted with ''a purpose to cause harm,'' the Supreme Court ruled today in a decision that resolved an important question of liability for law-enforcement tactics gone awry. The 9-to-0 decision, with six separate opinions that reflected a struggle within the Court over the definition of constitutional due process, made it unlikely that the police could be found liable for any but a handful of the several hundred deaths that occur every year from roughly 100,000 high-speed pursuits.

headline.main: Justices Allow Broad Leeway to Police Chases, Even Those Causing Deaths

docs.abstract: Supreme Court rules unanimously that high-speed police chases that cause death or injury do not violate Constitution unless police have acted with 'purpose to cause harm'; six separate opinions are issued, reflecting struggle over definition of due process, but ruling makes it unlikely that police can be found liable for any but handfull of several hundred deaths that occur each year from some 100,000 high-speed pursuits; Court overturns ruling in California suit by parents of teenage motorcyclist injured by patrol car; majority ruling by Justice David Souter says that when 'unforeseen circumstances demand officer's instant judgment, even precipitate recklessness fails to inch close enough to harmful purpose' to amount to constitutional liability; in separate case, Court refuses to hear appeal of South Carolina case in which two women were jailed for violating child endangerment law in giving birth to babies who tested positive for cocaine (M)
docs.snippet: High-speed police chases that cause death or injury do not violate the Constitution unless the police acted with ''a purpose to cause harm,'' the Supreme Court ruled today in a decision that resolved an important question of liability for...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A May 24 Associated Press news item reports that on July 1 South Dakota will become ''the first state to allow judges to order pregnant women who drink into alcoholism treatment.'' Wisconsin has also passed legislation allowing pregnant women who drink or use drugs to be detained until they give birth. The Legislature sent this bill to Gov. Tommy G. Thompson along with a feticide bill mandating life imprisonment for intentionally causing the death of a fetus.

headline.main: Fetal Protection Law Is Threat to Women

docs.abstract: Wendy R Sheldon letter, commenting on Frank Rich's May 20 column, disputes his description of conservative radio psychologist James C Dobson as 'Godzilla of the Right' (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Frank Rich's May 20 column, ''Godzilla of the Right,'' exemplified the current state of our political preoccupation with abortion and the alarming disintegration of church-state separation. Mr. Rich's descriptions of James C. Dobson, the religious right and the Republican Party alluded to abortion six times and mentioned school prayer, homosexuality and corporal punishment once each.

headline.main: Fetal Protection Law Is Threat to Women; Focus on Abortion

docs.abstract: Rachel Roth letter comments on May 24 news item on new South Dakota law under which pregnant women who drink can be ordered into alcoholism treatment; says defining drinking during pregnancy as child abuse erects police state for pregnant women, who can be locked up for reasons no one else can (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about assistants for women in childbirth misspelled the surname of a Kaiser Permanente obstetrician who said the assistants, or doulas, could help lower Caesarean rates. He is Dr. David M. Roth, not Ross.
docs.abstract: Correction of May 19 article on assistants for women in childbirth, which misspelled doctor's name
docs.snippet: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about assistants for women in childbirth misspelled the surname of a Kaiser Permanente obstetrician who said the assistants, or doulas, could help lower Caesarean rates. He is Dr. David M. Roth, not Ross.

docs.lead_paragraph: Massachusetts was buzzing this month with news that Jane Swift, a Republican candidate for lieutenant governor, is pregnant. Congratulations were not necessarily in order. ''The surprising thing is the way people keep telling me: 'I defended you,' '' says Ms. Swift, who was unaware until recently that her condition needed defending. Talk-radio callers claimed mothers-to-be should be nesting, not campaigning. An executive of the Christian Coalition predicted that Ms. Swift's pregnancy would spark discussions about whether children were better off at home with their parents or in ''institutional day care.'' This is ironic, considering that Ms. Swift could not be planning her situation better. Forget the Family Leave Act. If Congress really wanted to do right by the working mother, the Federal Government would guarantee her the option of serving as a lieutenant governor until her youngest child entered first grade. What other job combines pay, prestige and high visibility with a flexible schedule, low pressure and -- face it -- almost no actual duties? Lieutenant governors normally make up for the fact that they have nothing to do by covering for the main guy at political banquets and ribbon-cuttings. But if Ms. Swift wins the job and decides to cut back on the number of chicken dinners she attends, no taxpayer is going to complain about being underserved.

headline.main: Editorial Observer; Campaigning for Office on the Mommy Track

docs.abstract: Editorial Observer on poliical news in Massachusetts that Jane Swift, Republican candidate for lieutenant governor, is pregnant; quotes 33-year-old candidate's remark that campaign needs to 'get beyond my uterus'

docs.lead_paragraph: SHAWNNA wants to pull the covers up tight over her head and catch just a few more minutes of sleep. But her kids wake up early. They jump on her bed in the morning and plant kisses on her through the soft cotton sheets. They want juice, breakfast, her. Sometimes Shawnna feels as if her dreams are peeling away like flecks of paint. She became pregnant with her first child at 18. She dropped out of school, got involved in a troubled relationship, had a second baby, moved into public housing and began raising her children alone.

headline.main: Helping Young Moms Hold Fast to Dreams

docs.abstract: Article on writing and photography project for young women, part of Middlesex Hospital's Family Advocacy Program in Middletown, Conn; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: JESSENICA at 17 is no stranger to teen-age pregnancy. ''All my cousins and all my friends that I grew up with, they all have babies already,'' she said. ''They've been having babies since they were like 12 or whatever. And my mother was 15 when she had me.'' For many years Jessenica herself had longed to have a child. ''I wanted a baby to love me because I didn't think anyone would love me the way the baby would,'' Jessenica said. ''It would love me because I created it.''

headline.main: Doll Gives a Taste of Real Life

docs.abstract: Article on Baby Think It Over, plastic lifelike doll that simulates newborn, complete with random shrieking, that is part of program at Lindon Hill School in Hawthorne, NY, to help prevent teen-age pregnancies; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly 15 months after the publication of the landmark scientific paper announcing the creation of Dolly the sheep, the first paper has appeared extending cloning to another species. This time the clones are Holstein calves, created from genetically engineered fetal cells. The result is not other Dolly, because Dolly was made from an udder cell of an adult animal. The new feat, cloning from fetal calf cells, is easier because the younger the animal, the easier it is to clone its cells. But it has great practical importance, experts said. It means that scientists can slash the time to make a genetically engineered calf from three years, with current methods, to nine months, with cloning.

headline.main: Holstein Calves Cloned From Cells, Paper Says

docs.abstract: Cloning of Holstein calves, from fetal calf cells, is described in journal Science by Dr James M Robi of University of Massachusetts and Dr Steven L Stice of Advanced Cell Technologies; Stice also reports that research group has now produced four additional live calves from genetically-engineered fetal cells (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Partial-Birth Stratagem'' (editorial, May 16): Wisconsin doctors who shut down all abortions in response to a state law that bans a form of late-term abortion are a crafty lot who formed their own stratagem. Their ploy was not unlike the New York cabdrivers': work stoppage until they get their demands.
docs.abstract: Drew DeCoursey letter charges that Wisconsin doctors are crafty lot who shut down all abortions in deliberate response to new law banning form of late-term abortion

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''A Pregnant Candidate Discovers She's an Issue'' (news article, May 15): I wonder if conservative groups critical of 33-year-old Jane Swift, who is for running for lieutenant governor of Massachusetts while she is pregnant, would have been as critical of the Founders. Many of them left their wives, some of whom were pregnant and on isolated farms with as many as eight children, to go to Philadelphia to write the Constitution.
docs.abstract: George E Dean letter comments on May 15 article on controversy surrounding campaign of Jane Swift, who is running for lieutenant governor of Massachusetts while pregnant (S)
